Situation1: They occasionally ask their parents if everything is going well at home.
Situation2: They develop a floor plan for a new office, ensuring workspaces accommodate employees’ needs efficiently.
Story: I sat at my desk, blueprints spread out before me, tracing lines and calculating dimensions for the new office project. My phone buzzed—a message from Mom: “Can you call tonight? Dad’s been quiet lately.” I glanced at the clock. The deadline for the floor plan was tomorrow, and I still hadn’t figured out how to fit the break room without sacrificing workspace. My mind raced with measurements and layouts, but guilt crept in. I hadn’t checked in with my parents all week. They relied on me to notice when something was off, to ask if everything was okay at home. But right now, my clients expected a flawless design, one that balanced function and comfort for dozens of employees. I felt pulled in two directions—my parents needed my attention, my project demanded my focus. My heart ached with worry for them, but my mind spun with architectural details. I stared at my phone, torn, the weight of both roles pressing down on me.
